reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s use of “Common-sense utopia” as an intuitive benchmark and argues it’s chosen to make scale-sensitive views look fussy. This point is somewhat relevant (the benchmark is indeed small-scale and will systematically underperform on linear/scale-sensitive views), but it is not central to the paper’s overall case, which also rests heavily on the broader ‘many independent moral pitfalls’ argument and (especially) Section 3’s more general claims about linearity/boundedness and fussiness. Even if the benchmark were changed, much of the argument could stand. The critique’s main overreach is claiming the paper’s conclusion “depends entirely” on this benchmarking and that it’s “deliberately” constructed; that seems false/unsupported given the paper’s broader and more systematic argumentation and its explicit discussion of scale. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight, but it only modestly weakens a non-essential part of the overall position.
title: The common-sense utopia benchmark is gerrymandered to favor scale-insensitive views
